questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a myeloid marker?
questions.explanation:
CD3 is not a myeloid marker. It is a T-cell lymphoid marker. Cell markers: 474 
Sold by @itachibot • B-cell: CD10, CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23, CD24, CD79b, CD103, Pax-5, kappa, lambda, CD200, 
cytoplasmic kappa, cytoplasmic lambda • T- cell: CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD6,CD7, CD8, TCR apha-beta, TCR gamma-delta, 
cytoplasmic CD3 • Myeloid: CD11b, CD13, CD14, CD15, CD33, CD64, CD 117, myeloperoxidase

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is the most common type of acute myeloid leukemia?
questions.explanation: The most common type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is AML - M2 or AML with maturation. The least common type of AML is AML M7 or megakaryocytic.

questions.question:
Question 3: What is the most common subtype of acute myeloid leukemia seen in patients with Down's 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common subtype of AML seen in Down's syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia-M7 (AML 
- M7) or acute megakaryocytic leukemia. Myeloid proliferations of Down's syndrome are usually megakaryoblastic. It includes: • Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) - occurs at birth or within days of birth and resolves in 1 
to 2 months • Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome - occurs later, but usually in the first 3 years 
of life. Both are characterized by GATA1 mutations and mutations of the JAK-STAT pathway.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab 
investigations show the following findings. The blasts are positive for CD33. What is the most 
likely diagnosis? 467 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that 
impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It 
occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, 
and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for 
CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow 
examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.

questions.question:
Question 5: Peripheral smear of a patient with acute promyelocytic leukemia shows myeloblasts with the 
following finding. What are these made of?
questions.explanation:
The image shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. These are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic 
inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. 475 
Sold by @itachibot Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are 
called faggot cells and are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following conditions are Auer rods seen?
questions.explanation: Auer rods are seen in: • Acute promyelocytic leukemia • Myelodysplastic syndromes • Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia These are not seen in acute monocytic leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood 
smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.explanation:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a 
bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of 
sticks). Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods). Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but 
particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia). Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking 
on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding 
cellular matrix. Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as 
dusky promyelocytes.

questions.question:
Question 8: Increased levels of serum muramidase are seen in patients with which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
Serum muramidase or lysozyme levels are seen to be increased in patients with acute 
myelomonocytic leukemia (AML - M4). It is also increased in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

questions.question: Question 9: Which type of AML is known as Di Guglielmo disease?
questions.explanation:
Acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) or acute erythroid leukemia is known as Di Guglielmo 
disease. AML-M6 accounts for 1% of AML cases. It has two subtypes: 476 
Sold by @itachibot • Erythroid/myeloid leukemia (M6a, more common) - Dyserythropoiesis is prominent • Pure erythroid leukemia/ erythemic myelosis/ Di Guglielmo disease (M6b, rare) - >80% 
erythroid precursors. Clinical findings include anemia, thrombocytopenia, and variable 
neutropenia. Positive stains for erythroid cells are glycophorin A, hemoglobin A, CD36, CD71, CD117, and PAS.

questions.question:
Question 10: In patients with which of the following conditions, a dry tap may be seen on bone marrow 
aspiration?
questions.explanation:
Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML M7) may yield a dry tap on marrow aspiration. It may be associated with extensive bone marrow fibrosis as a result of the stimulation of the 
normal fibroblasts by the local secretion of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) by the leukemic 
cells.

questions.question:
Question 11: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia shows the 
presence of faggot cells. What is the most likely subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, the 
patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
The presence of faggot cells is highly suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia - M3 (AML - M3) or 
acute promyelocytic leukemia. A cluster of Auer rods is known as a faggot cell. It is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia 
(AML) M3. The image given below shows AML M3 with a cluster of Auer rods (faggot cell).

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia presents with a one-day history of bleeding 
gums, subconjunctival bleed, and purpuric rash. Investigations done are given below. Which 
of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?
questions.explanation:
477 
Sold by @itachibot The patient shows features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It is most likely to be 
associated with acute myeloid leukemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia. The pathogenesis 
behind this is t(15,17) or PML-RARA fusion gene. Option A: Inversion 16 is seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia or AML - M4. Option B: t(8;21) is seen in AML with differentiation or AML - M2. Option C: Inversion 3 is seen in AML - M7 (megakaryoblastic) which shows normal or increased 
platelet count. It has a poor prognosis.

questions.question: Question 13: Which type of acute myeloid leukemia is myeloperoxidase negative?
questions.explanation:
AML M0 is negative for myeloperoxidase (MPO). AML-M5 (monocytic), AML-M6 (erythroid), and 
AML-M7 (megakaryocytic) are also negative for MPO. Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is located in the primary granules of neutrophils and their precursors, in 
eosinophil granules, and in the azurophilic granules of monocytes. The most primitive myeloblasts are negative, with granular positivity appearing progressively as 
they mature toward the promyelocyte stage. Promyelocytes and myelocytes are the most strongly 
staining cells in the granulocyte series. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. AML-M4 shows both myelocytic and monocytic differentiation. Hence, it shows both MPO and 
non-specific esterase (marker for monocytes) positivity.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with fatigue and recurrent infections undergoes bone marrow evaluation. It shows 
> 20% myeloblasts, which stain positive for CD61. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with myeloblasts that stain positive for CD61 is suggestive of acute 
megakaryocytic leukemia (AML-M7). AML M7 is the least common type of AML. Blasts of megakaryocytic lineage predominate and are 
associated with marrow fibrosis. There is also frequent budding of cytoplasmic margins. They are CD41+ and CD61+. They stain negatively with Sudan black B (SBB) and myeloperoxidase 
(MPO). Blasts are reactive with PAS and acid phosphatase. The prognosis for this type of acute leukemia is poor.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient who developed the following lesions over the body was diagnosed with acute 
myeloid leukemia. Which subtype of AML does this patient most likely have? 471 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows leukemia cutis. It is seen in acute myeloid leukemia - M4 and acute 
myeloid leukemia - M5. It refers to leukemic cells infiltrating the skin. Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less 
striking in AML than in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). But tumors with monocytic 
differentiation (AML M4, M5) often infiltrate the skin (leukemia cutis) and the gingiva. This 
probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues. 478 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, 
hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Investigations done are given below. Bone 
marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity with many blasts cells that are peroxidase negative 
and non-specific esterase positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia-M5 (AML-M5) or acute 
monocytic leukemia. The patients with AML - M5 develop organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, C•S 
involvement, and other tissue infiltration. The bone marrow aspirate shows 20% or more 
blasts. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase 
positive. Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and their precursors. It is 
positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be 
negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely 
scattered throughout the cytoplasm. The image given below shows bone marrow aspirate in AML - M5.

questions.question:
Question 17: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. After evaluation, he is diagnosed with chloroma. 
Which of the following is not a marker for this condition?
questions.explanation:
CD61 is a marker of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, not chloroma. Lysozyme, CD43, CD45, 
CD117, and MPO are positive markers of chloroma. Chloroma, also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or myeloblastoma is an 
extramedullary tumor that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with AML. Frequent sites of 
involvement are: • Skin • Lymph nodes • Gastrointestinal tract 479 
Sold by @itachibot • Bone • Soft tissue, testis • Peritoneum Orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare without any evidence of systemic 
involvement. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal 
swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity 
and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

questions.question: Question 18: In which of the following conditions are Arbiskov cells seen?
questions.explanation:
Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma. Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a hematopoietic stem cell tumor, 
where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites. Orbit is one of the most common sites of 
occurrences in pediatric population. It is seen in AML - M2 most commonly. Other conditions 
associated are myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes. The image given below shows Arbiskov cells in chloroma.

questions.question:
Question 19: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the 
following genetic aberrations?
questions.explanation:
All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), 
which is associated with PML-RARA fusion gene. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between 
chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes for a 
chimeric protein, which consists of a part of the PML protein and a part of the retinoic acid 
receptor- (RAR). 480 
Sold by @itachibot The normal RAR binds to the D•A and activates the transcription in the presence of retinoids. 
However, the chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA has reduced affinity for retinoids. This 
causes inhibition of transcription, thereby preventing gene expression for cellular differentiation. 
This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells. The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. 
This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates 
D•A transcription.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following cytogenetic changes suggest a favorable prognosis in patients with 
acute myeloid leukemia?

options.a: t (11q23;v) with diverse MLL fusion genes

questions.explanation:
•ormal karyotyping with mutated •PM indicates a favorable prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia 
(AML).

questions.question: Question 21: Which among the following patients with acute myeloid leukemia has a good prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Inversion 16 is associated with a good prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 481 
Sold by @itachibot Hodgkin's Lymphoma
